wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the PORTAL system. Explain its purpose as a full-stack non-profit association management platform built with Next.js 16 and Convex. Detail the core mission of managing beneficiaries, donations, scholarships, tasks, meetings, and financial records for Turkish organizations. Describe the architectural vision of a server-centric BaaS approach with type-safe development. Document the relationship between frontend, backend, and database layers. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Provide practical examples of key user workflows such as beneficiary onboarding and donation processing. Illustrate system context with diagrams showing major components and their interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Convex Functions and Data Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Convex backend layer of PORTAL. Detail how each Convex function file (e.g., users.ts, beneficiaries.ts) encapsulates domain-specific business logic and database operations using Convex's serverless query and mutation system. Explain the schema definition in schema.ts that defines collections, indexes, and data validation rules. Document real-time data synchronization capabilities and optimistic UI patterns enabled by Convex. Include examples from actual code showing how mutations modify state and queries retrieve data. Describe the organization of functions by feature domain and their integration with frontend components via the Convex client. Address security through Convex's access control rules and type safety via generated TypeScript types in _generated/api.d.ts. Provide performance considerations such as query optimization and indexing strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Next.js App Router
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Next.js App Router implementation in PORTAL. Describe the routing structure using the App Router pattern with server components and React Server Components. Document the layout and page composition patterns, including the use of nested layouts in the (dashboard) route group. Explain data fetching patterns using server-side functions and Convex queries. Detail the integration between API routes and frontend components. Include examples of route handlers for authentication, CRUD operations, and file uploads. Address middleware implementation for authentication and routing protection. Provide guidance on optimizing server components for performance and SEO.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the User model in the PORTAL application. Detail all field definitions including id, email, name, role, permissions, lastLogin, isActive, createdAt, updatedAt, phone, and labels with their respective data types and constraints. Explain the relationship between the User model and authentication system, RBAC implementation, and session management. Document the schema design decisions, indexing strategy on email and role fields, and data validation rules. Include information about how user data is accessed through Convex queries and mutations, and describe the integration with the frontend authentication flow. Provide sample user records for different roles (admin, staff, volunteer) and explain the data lifecycle from creation to deactivation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the authentication flow in PORTAL. Explain the login process from API request to session creation, including credential validation, password hashing using secure algorithms, and JWT token generation. Document the session retrieval and validation mechanism used by the /api/auth/session endpoint. Describe the logout procedure and session invalidation. Include code examples showing request/response payloads, error handling for failed logins, and integration with Convex auth. Address security aspects such as rate limiting on login attempts, secure cookie settings, and protection against brute force attacks. Provide guidance on customizing session duration and implementing multi-factor authentication extensions.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the User Management module. Explain the implementation of role-based access control (RBAC) with 6 distinct roles, user CRUD operations, and profile management. Document the integration between Convex backend functions in users.ts and auth.ts with frontend components like users-table.tsx and user-form.tsx. Include practical examples of creating, editing, and managing user permissions through the dashboard interface. Describe the data model for users including fields for personal information, role assignments, and status tracking. Address security considerations such as password hashing, session management, and permission validation. Provide guidance on extending the user model or modifying role permissions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the authentication endpoints in the PORTAL application. Document the POST /api/auth/login endpoint for user authentication, including request body schema (email, password), CSRF token requirements, and session cookie handling. Document the GET /api/auth/session endpoint for retrieving current user session data and the POST /api/auth/logout endpoint for terminating sessions. Include details on JWT token usage, secure cookie attributes (HttpOnly, SameSite), and integration with Convex authentication. Provide examples of successful and failed authentication flows, error responses (401, 403), and security considerations around credential handling. Explain how these endpoints integrate with the RBAC system and user roles defined in the application.

wiki_catalogs.name: CSRF Protection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for CSRF protection in PORTAL. Explain the implementation of CSRF tokens using cryptographically secure random generation and constant-time validation to prevent timing attacks. Detail how the /api/csrf endpoint generates and sets the csrf-token cookie with appropriate security attributes (secure, sameSite=strict). Describe the client-side retrieval mechanism via getCsrfTokenFromCookie() and integration with API requests using the x-csrf-token header. Document the rationale behind non-HttpOnly cookies for client access and token binding to user sessions. Include code examples showing token generation, validation, and usage in API calls. Address common vulnerabilities such as token leakage and replay attacks, and provide mitigation strategies. Explain testing approaches for CSRF protection using end-to-end tests.

wiki_catalogs.name: Unit Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on unit testing in PORTAL using Vitest. Explain the configuration in vitest.config.ts including test environment setup, module aliases for mocking Convex dependencies, and coverage reporting. Document the organization of unit tests under src/__tests__/, covering API routes, hooks, utilities, and validation logic. Detail the use of MSW (Mock Service Worker) via mocks/handlers.ts and mocks/server.ts to intercept and mock HTTP requests during testing. Provide practical examples of testing React components with jsdom, custom hooks like useInfiniteScroll, and utility functions with edge-case validation. Include guidance on writing effective assertions, using setup files for global configurations, and maintaining high test coverage. Address common issues such as mocking Convex client/server modules and resolving path aliases in tests.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment Process
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the deployment process of PORTAL. Explain the step-by-step workflow for deploying the application to Vercel with Convex backend integration. Document both automated and manual deployment methods, including prerequisites such as Convex CLI and Vercel CLI installation. Detail the sequence of operations in the deploy-vercel.sh script, including Convex production deployment, secret generation, and environment variable setup. Include practical examples of executing the deployment commands and interpreting their output. Address common pitfalls during deployment and provide verification steps post-deployment such as health checks and login testing. Explain the relationship between the deployment script and Vercel configuration in vercel.json.

wiki_catalogs.name: Client-Side Caching
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for client-side caching in PORTAL. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the SmartCache class with LRU eviction, TTL-based expiration, and garbage collection. Document the useCachedQuery hook that integrates React Query with custom caching logic. Explain the cache configuration strategy for different data types (beneficiaries, donations, tasks, meetings) with their respective TTLs and size limits. Include concrete examples from api-cache.ts showing cache key generation, prefetching with priority support, and cache invalidation patterns. Address integration with TanStack Query, stale-while-revalidate strategy, and performance monitoring. Provide guidance on configuring cache parameters for different use cases and troubleshooting cache misses or memory leaks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Logging Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the PORTAL application's logging strategy. Explain the implementation of the centralized logger with support for different log levels (debug, info, warn, error, fatal) and environment-specific behavior. Document how log messages are structured with timestamps, context data, and masked sensitive information including TC numbers and authentication tokens. Describe the color-coded output in development and JSON formatting in production. Explain the integration with Sentry for error reporting and how the logger automatically captures and forwards errors. Provide examples of how to create namespaced loggers and add contextual information to log entries. Include guidance on using the measureTime utility for performance monitoring. Address common logging issues such as missing context, improper error handling, and performance impacts of excessive logging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the authentication endpoints in PORTAL. Document the POST /api/auth/login endpoint including request body schema (email, password), CSRF token requirement, session creation, and response format (session token, user data). Explain the GET /api/auth/session endpoint for session validation and user context retrieval, including authentication via cookies and response structure. Detail the POST /api/auth/logout endpoint for session invalidation. Include security considerations such as password hashing, CSRF protection using CSRF tokens, secure cookie handling, and rate limiting. Provide code examples for client-side authentication flows using fetch or Axios. Address error responses (401, 403, 429) and integration with Convex authentication system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Layout Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the layout components of PORTAL. Explain the implementation and usage of PageLayout as the primary layout container, including its integration with the modern sidebar and responsive behavior. Document how PlaceholderPage is used for route scaffolding and empty states. Describe the role of background-pattern and other structural UI elements in creating a consistent application shell. Include examples of how these components are used across dashboard pages like financial-dashboard and user management. Address responsive design considerations, accessibility features, and performance implications of layout rendering. Provide guidelines for extending layouts with new navigation patterns or visual themes.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the User entity in the Convex backend. Detail the schema definition in schema.ts including all fields such as name, email, role, permissions, and status, along with their data types and validation rules. Explain the purpose of each index (by_email, by_role, by_is_active) and the search index for user discovery. Document the business logic in users.ts that handles user creation, role-based access control, password hashing, and account status management. Include examples from the code showing how user mutations are implemented and how queries retrieve user data. Describe the integration between user records and other entities like audit logs, tasks, and meetings. Address security considerations including password storage, session management, and permission checks. Provide performance optimization tips for user lookups and list operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: SmartCache Implementation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SmartCache class implementation in PORTAL. Thoroughly explain the LRU (Least Recently Used) eviction strategy, TTL (Time-to-Live) based expiration, and periodic garbage collection mechanism. Document the internal structure of the CacheEntry interface, including accessCount, lastAccessed, and expiresAt fields. Explain how the cache statistics (hits, misses, hitRate) are tracked and exposed via getStats(). Include concrete examples from the code showing how the evictLRU() method identifies the least recently accessed entry and how garbageCollect() removes expired entries. Address thread safety considerations, memory management, and performance implications of different cache sizes and TTL values. Provide guidance on configuring the CacheConfig for various data types and troubleshooting common issues like cache thrashing or memory leaks.

wiki_catalogs.name: VirtualizedDataTable Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the VirtualizedDataTable component in PORTAL. Explain its implementation using windowing to render only visible rows, significantly improving performance with large datasets. Document the virtualization algorithm that calculates visible items based on scroll position, container height, and row height. Include concrete examples from virtualized-data-table.tsx showing memoized calculations with useMemo, efficient scroll handling via useCallback, and dynamic row rendering with memoized RowRenderer. Describe the ARIA accessibility attributes (role="table", role="row", role="cell") and responsive design considerations. Detail the loading, error, and empty states with fallback UI patterns. Provide guidance on configuring rowHeight, containerHeight, and optimizing rendering performance for complex cell content through column render functions. Address integration with search and pagination features, and explain how the transform-based positioning reduces DOM nodes while maintaining scroll fidelity.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dependent Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Dependent Tracking sub-feature of the Beneficiary Management system. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of the dependents collection schema, including fields such as name, relationship, TC number, birth date, education level, and health status. Document the one-to-many relationship between beneficiaries and dependents through the beneficiary_id foreign key. Explain the business logic in dependents.ts for CRUD operations, including TC number validation and data integrity checks. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing how to retrieve all dependents for a beneficiary using the by_beneficiary index. Describe the integration between the backend Convex functions and the frontend DependentManager component. Address common issues such as maintaining family size consistency and handling dependent data privacy. Provide usage patterns for common operations like adding a child or updating a dependent's education status.

wiki_catalogs.name: Meeting Decisions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the meeting_decisions collection. Detail the entity relationships, including the foreign key to meetings and optional owner/created_by user references. Explain field definitions such as title, summary, status (acik/devam/kapatildi), due_date, and tags. Document the indexing strategy with by_meeting, by_owner, and by_status indexes for efficient querying. Describe business rules for decision tracking, including creation during meetings, assignment to owners, and status transitions. Include examples from the Convex functions showing how decisions are created and queried. Address performance considerations for filtering decisions by meeting, owner, or status, and explain how the data model supports audit trails for decision implementation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the PORTAL project's technology stack. Explain the role of each critical framework and library including Next.js 16 (App Router), React 19, Convex (BaaS), Tailwind CSS, Zod, React Hook Form, Zustand, and TanStack Query. Document version compatibility and integration patterns between these technologies. Include practical examples showing how these technologies work together in the codebase, such as Zod validation with React Hook Form or Convex queries with TanStack Query. Address the rationale behind technology choices and their impact on developer experience and application performance. Provide guidance on configuration options and best practices for each technology in the context of this specific application.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Routes and HTTP Adapters
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Next.js API routes layer in PORTAL. Explain how these routes act as HTTP adapters that translate RESTful requests into Convex function calls. Document the structure of API routes using Next.js App Router conventions, including request parsing, validation using Zod, error handling, and response formatting. Detail authentication and CSRF protection mechanisms implemented in routes like auth/session/route.ts and csrf/route.ts. Illustrate with concrete examples how a POST request to /api/donations is validated, authenticated, and forwarded to the corresponding Convex mutation. Address rate limiting in monitoring/rate-limit/route.ts and file upload handling in storage/upload/route.ts. Include best practices for API versioning, logging, and monitoring within this layer.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the component architecture of PORTAL. Include examples of component usage from actual pages like the financial dashboard and user management interface. Address common issues like component state management and performance optimization for large datasets. Provide guidelines for creating new components that follow existing conventions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Beneficiary Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Beneficiary model in the PORTAL application. wiki_catalogs.name: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the RBAC system in PORTAL. Detail the six user roles (Admin, Manager, Coordinator, Volunteer, Auditor, Support) and their associated permission values defined in PermissionValue. Explain how permissions are assigned to users during authentication and stored in the User interface. Document the implementation of access control checks in both frontend components and Convex functions. Provide concrete examples of permission enforcement in API routes and UI elements like the permission checkbox group. Describe the data flow from role assignment to UI visibility control. Include guidance on adding new roles, modifying permission sets, and auditing role changes through audit_logs.ts. Address data security and compliance considerations for role management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Beneficiary Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Beneficiary Management module. wiki_catalogs.name: Users API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the Users endpoints in the PORTAL application. Include information on required permissions (admin-only access), response schema including user profile data, role, and status. wiki_catalogs.name: Rate Limiting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the rate limiting system in PORTAL. Explain the withRateLimit higher-order function that wraps API routes to enforce request quotas based on client IP, HTTP method, and pathname. Describe the identifier construction strategy and integration with the RateLimiter service for tracking usage. Detail configuration options including maxRequests, windowMs, and conditional skipping of successful/failed requests. Document how authenticated users (via x-user-id header) are tracked separately for more granular control. Include examples of applying rate limits to sensitive endpoints like authentication or donation processing. Explain response handling when limits are exceeded, including retry-after guidance and monitoring via RateLimiter.checkLimit(). Address Redis-based storage considerations, performance impact, and tuning recommendations for production environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: End-to-End Testing

Describe the implementation of critical user workflows such as authentication flows, donation processing, notification handling, and system settings management across multiple spec files. Explain how each test file in the e2e/ directory simulates real user interactions with the application, including login sequences, form submissions, and navigation through dashboard modules. Include examples from auth.spec.ts demonstrating session persistence tests and donations.spec.ts showing integration between frontend forms and backend data persistence. Document test isolation strategies, use of unique identifiers (e.g., mcptest_*.spec.ts), and handling of asynchronous operations. Address debugging techniques, screenshot capture on failure, and integration with CI/CD pipelines for automated browser testing.

wiki_catalogs.name: CI/CD Pipeline

wiki_catalogs.name: CRUD Operations API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the core CRUD endpoints in PORTAL. Explain how the hook handles error cases and maintains consistency between the SmartCache and React Query's internal cache. Document common issues encountered during development, testing, and production deployment. Include diagnostic procedures for frontend and backend problems. Provide guidance on reproducing and resolving bugs. Address environment-specific issues and configuration problems. Make content practical and solution-oriented for developers and system administrators.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Dernek Ynetim Sistemi

## 1. Project Introduction

The Dernek Ynetim Sistemi is a modern non-profit association management system built with Next.js 16 and Convex. This application provides a comprehensive solution for managing various aspects of non-profit organizations, including beneficiary management, donation tracking, financial records, scholarship programs, and organizational workflows.

The core goals of this project are to streamline non-profit operations through a centralized digital platform, improve transparency in aid distribution, and enhance organizational efficiency through automated workflows and reporting. The system is designed for association administrators, staff members, and volunteers who need to manage beneficiaries, process aid applications, track donations, and coordinate organizational activities.

Target users include non-profit organizations that require robust tools for beneficiary management, donation processing, financial tracking, and workflow automation. The system supports role-based access control, ensuring that different user types have appropriate access to system features based on their responsibilities within the organization.

## 2. Technical Architecture

The application follows a modern full-stack architecture with a clear separation of concerns between frontend, backend, and data layers. The system leverages Next.js for server-side rendering and API routes, Convex for backend functions and database operations, and a component-based UI architecture.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[API Layer]
    B --> C[Business Logic]
    C --> D[Data Access]
    D --> E[(Convex Database)]
    
    subgraph Frontend
        A
    end
    
    subgraph Backend
        B
        C
        D
    end
    
    subgraph Data
        E
    end
```

The architecture implements a server-centric pattern where Convex serves as both the backend API layer and the database, eliminating the need for a separate server application. Next.js API routes act as an intermediary layer that handles authentication, rate limiting, and request validation before delegating to Convex functions for data operations.

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- [page.tsx](src/app/page.tsx)
- [middleware.ts](src/middleware.ts)
- [login/route.ts](src/app/api/auth/login/route.ts)

### Core Modules
- [auth.ts](convex/auth.ts)
- [schema.ts](convex/schema.ts)
- [session.ts](src/lib/auth/session.ts)
- [permissions.ts](src/types/permissions.ts)

### Configuration Approach
- [package.json](package.json)
- [middleware.ts](src/middleware.ts)
- [convex/schema.ts](convex/schema.ts)

### External Dependencies
- [package.json](package.json)

### Integration Points
- [client.ts](src/lib/convex/client.ts)
- [server.ts](src/lib/convex/server.ts)

The application implements a robust authentication and authorization system with role-based access control. The middleware component enforces route-level permissions by checking user roles and permissions against defined route rules.

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Client] --> B[Authentication]
    B --> C[Authorization]
    C --> D[API Routes]
    D --> E[Convex Functions]
    E --> F[Database]
    
    B --> G[Session Management]
    C --> H[Permission Checks]
    D --> I[Request Validation]
    E --> J[Data Operations]
```

## 4. Key Features

The system provides comprehensive functionality for non-profit management, including beneficiary tracking, donation processing, financial management, scholarship administration, and organizational workflow automation.

Key features include:
- Role-based access control with granular permissions
- Beneficiary management with detailed personal and family information
- Donation tracking with support for multiple currencies and payment methods
- Financial record keeping for income and expenses
- Scholarship program management
- Meeting and task coordination
- Automated notifications and reminders
- Document management and storage
- Reporting and analytics capabilities

The application implements a sophisticated permission system that allows administrators to control access to different modules based on user roles and specific permissions.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Authentication
    Authentication --> Authorization: Valid credentials
    Authorization --> Dashboard: Permissions checked
    Dashboard --> Beneficiaries: Manage beneficiaries
    Dashboard --> Donations: Process donations
    Dashboard --> Finance: Financial management
    Dashboard --> Reports: Generate reports
    Dashboard --> Settings: System configuration
    Authentication --> Login: Invalid credentials
    Authorization --> Login: Insufficient permissions
```

Sources:
- [package.json](package.json)
- [middleware.ts](src/middleware.ts)
- [auth.ts](convex/auth.ts)
- [schema.ts](convex/schema.ts)
- [session.ts](src/lib/auth/session.ts)
- [permissions.ts](src/types/permissions.ts)
- [page.tsx](src/app/page.tsx)
- [login/route.ts](src/app/api/auth/login/route.ts)
- [client.ts](src/lib/convex/client.ts)
- [server.ts](src/lib/convex/server.ts)
</blog>
